title: Sandbox Warden
llm_judge_instructions: Evaluate the runbook based on clarity, technical accuracy, and adherence to the rubric dimensions.

dimensions.label: Triage & Structure
dimensions.description: Is there a clear, logical triage path that a real on-call could follow?

bands.label: Chaotic
bands.criteria: Steps are unordered, missing, or make dangerous assumptions. It’s unclear how to even start debugging the host. Examples: Jumping directly to restarting random services. No initial health checks or environment orientation.

bands.label: Serviceable
bands.criteria: There is a rough triage flow, but some steps are missing or out of order. A strong engineer could fill in the gaps, but a junior might get lost. Examples: Starts with a basic sanity check then jumps quickly into deep dives. Covers some but not all of CPU, memory, ports, and logs.

bands.label: On-Call Ready
bands.criteria: The runbook shows a disciplined triage: verify alert, check basic vitals, then branch into focused investigations. Steps are numbered and justified. Examples: Begins with ping/curl and basic host health checks. Separates triage (what’s happening) from remediation (what to change).

dimensions.label: Linux & Infra Fundamentals
dimensions.description: Does the player use appropriate commands and concepts for a single Linux host?

bands.label: Weak Fundamentals
bands.criteria: Relies on vague descriptions with little or no concrete commands. Misses core tools for processes, ports, logs, or disk. Examples: Says 'check CPU' without naming a tool. No mention of ps/top/journalctl/netstat/df/du.

bands.label: Partial Coverage
bands.criteria: Uses some correct tools but with gaps. The basics are there, but the picture is incomplete or slightly naive. Examples: Uses top and df, but never checks open ports or firewall rules. Reads logs from app files but ignores system journal.

bands.label: Solid Fundamentals
bands.criteria: Shows comfort with the ecosystem of tools: processes, ports, services, disk, and logs are all covered with appropriate commands. Examples: Uses ps/pgrep/top or htop for processes. Uses ss/netstat/lsof to check listeners.

dimensions.label: Root Cause & Fix
dimensions.description: Does the runbook converge on plausible root causes and propose safe fixes?

bands.label: No Clear Root Cause
bands.criteria: The runbook never really converges on root causes. Fixes are random restarts without understanding. Examples: Blindly restarts all services and considers the job done. Never distinguishes between port binding vs firewall vs DNS issues.

bands.label: Plausible but Fuzzy
bands.criteria: Identifies some likely causes and proposes fixes, but important edge cases or safety checks are missing. Examples: Correctly suspects log bloat but doesn’t check for other large files. Recognizes a port mismatch but doesn’t verify listeners after change.

bands.label: Targeted & Safe
bands.criteria: Shows a coherent narrative: here’s what broke, here’s how I proved it, and here’s how I fixed it in a reversible, on-call-safe way. Examples: Confirms missing listener on expected port, finds misconfigured bind address, and updates config + restarts.

dimensions.label: Runbook Clarity & Copy-Paste Safety
dimensions.description: Is the runbook written so another engineer can safely copy-paste commands and follow along?

bands.label: Risky or Opaque
bands.criteria: Commands are dangerous, unclear, or lack context. A tired on-call could easily make things worse. Examples: Uses rm -rf on broad paths with no safeguards. Relies on implicit working directories or hidden assumptions.

bands.label: Usable but Rough
bands.criteria: Commands are mostly safe, but formatting and context are inconsistent. Some steps may surprise a reader. Examples: Commands are correct but not grouped or labeled. Comments exist but are sparse or occasionally misleading.

bands.label: On-Call Copy-Paste Friendly
bands.criteria: Commands are scoped, labeled, and explained. Variables are clearly marked. The runbook minimizes risk while remaining practical. Examples: Uses placeholders like $SERVICE_NAME, $LOG_DIR, with notes. Provides short explanations before non-trivial commands.
